IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy new men’s and children’s shoes.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en:
Thuy was born in 1979. She lives in Xom Vang village. She is married with two children who are small. Her husband is a businessman. 

Mrs Thuy has a wedding dress shop (selling and renting out wedding dresses). She has this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 3,500,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2007. 

The last time, she borrowed 7,194,000 VND and repaid punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 8,502,000 VND to buy more new wedding dress to renting out.

loans.use: to buy more new wedding dress for renting service

loans.name: Ryskul's Group

texts.en:
Ryskul is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married to a security guard. Together with her husband she takes care of two grandchildren, both of whom study at school. In order to earn additional money for the family budget, Ryskul’s husband also works in construction. 

Three years ago, with an initial investment of 5000 soms, Rysku started to breed livestock and then resell it after fattening. She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to increase the number of livestock. She wants to purchase six farm animals for breeding, fattening and further reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a variety of vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, aged 32 years, is married to Patrick. They have  one child aged ten years. She runs a restaurant and catering services. She has been in this business for a period of three years now. With this loan, she plans to buy more rice, wheat and maize flour for her business.

From the anticipated profit she hopes to expand her restaurant due to the increase of customers on a daily basis.

She desires to own a decent restaurant in Nairobi business center.

loans.use: to buy rice, maize and wheat flour.

loans.name: Elizaveta's Group

texts.en: Elizaveta is the leader of this group. She is 38 and married; her husband went to work in Russia to make money. Elizaveta takes care of two daughters; the older daughter studies at school and the younger is preschool age (under 7). Elizaveta works as an administrator in the hotel; her monthly salary is 7000 soms. She applied for the loan because she needs money to improve their living conditions; the loan purpose is the purchase of a gas cooker. In the future, she wants to save some money to repair an apartment and purchase new furniture home. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a gas cooker.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Adelaida is married and has two children. She is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. Adelaida is a farmer who grows corn to earn a living. She has been doing this for five years. She has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers for her corn production. Adelaida has been a member of PMPC for one year.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for corn production

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 47-year-old lady who has two children, ages 7 and 12. She has operated her business for three years. With this loan, she plans to buy a container of human drugs/ medicine from Uganda so that she can have enough inventory for her shop in Nairobi, Kenya. 

From the anticipated profits, she will pay her children's eduction expenses. She dreams of becoming a leading pharmaceutical supplier in Nairobi.

loans.use: to buy drugs and medicines

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy, 38 years old, is a mother of three children, ages 13, 10, and 6. She is raising chickens for sale. She also keeps layer hens for eggs. She has been in this business for three years. With this loan, she plans to buy chicken feed and more layer hens so that she can get better returns.

From the anticipated profits, she hopes to add more chicks and build a better house for her family. She also desires and plans to give her children a good education.

loans.use: to buy food for her chickens and more layer hens

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a charcoal vendor. She is unmarried and has two children, ages 15 and 18.  She has been engaged in this business for a period of six years. With this loan, she plans to buy more charcoal to offer for sale.

From the anticipated profits, she plans to open a stall within the town and expand the business. In future, she desires to provide her children with a good education and also to buy a plot of land and build for her family.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to offer for sale

loans.name: Ndunda

texts.en:
Ndunda, age 35, operates a green grocery and has been running this business for the last nine years. This is the third loan he has received from KADET Ltd., and he intends to use it to buy vegetables and other food items to offer for sale from his stall. He and his wife have five children.

From the anticipated profits, he plans to expand his business. He hopes to own a bigger business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to offer for sale in for his stall

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 36 years old, married and has two children. 

Haydar has had a store since 2002, selling electrical installations and bathroom and kitchen materials. He has a long experience in this field and a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2100 to make an advertising light box and to rent an extra store. He is aiming to earn more profit to improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To make an advertising light box and to rent an extra store.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, age 33, is a cereals vendor. She has been in this business for a period of nine years. She and her husband have two children.

With this loan, she plans to add stock to her cereals sales business. She intends to use the profits to eventually build a permanent house for her family. 

She desires to own a bigger cereal shop in the near future.

loans.use: to buy stocks of cereals to offer for sale

loans.name: Kerimbubu

texts.ru:
Керимбубу 61 год, замужем, имеет двоих детей.  Керимбубу окончила Фрунзенский Финансово- Экономический техникум и долгое время проработала бухгалтером – кассиром.  В 1999 году, в целях нахождения дополнительного источника доходов для своей семьи,   клиентка начала заниматься животноводством и полеводством. На сегодняшний день, в собственности у семьи имеется 1 дойная  корова, один  теленок и  10 баранов. Также у Керимбубу имеется  7,0 га орошаемой земли с многолетними травами и фасолью.  Два года назад Керимбубу уже обращалась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50, 000 сом (KGS), который погасила  без нарушений.  Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса,   Керимбубу запрашивает кредит в сумме 70, 000 сом для увеличения поголовья  скота и перепродажи. 
ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" (CJSC “Bai Tushum & Partners” MFC) предоставляет кредиты по линии Кива для социально-уязвимых слоев населения. ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" является одной из лидирующих Микрофинансовых организаций Кыргызстана. "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" – это надежный финансовый партнер, осуществляющий вклад в развитие экономики Кыргызской Республики путем предоставления доступных микрофинансовых услуг в сельской местности и городах, способствующих созданию рабочих мест и отвечающий интересам своих клиентов и инвесторов.
texts.en:
Kerimbubu is 61 years old and married with two children. Kerimbubu graduated from the Frunze Financial and Economic College and worked in an accounting department for a long time as a cashier. In 1999, in order to find an additional source of income for her family, the client began to work in farming and animal husbandry. Now the family has a milk cow, one calf, and ten sheep. Also Kerimbubu has seven hectares of irrigated land which she has sown with perennial grasses and beans. Two years ago, Kerimbubu asked Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 50,000 som (KGS), which she paid off with no problems. To further development her business, Kerimbubu requests a loan of 70,000 som (KGS) to increase her livestock for resale.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock of detergent, coffee, tea and rice.

loans.name: Freda

texts.en:
Freda, who is 58 years old, sells cloth goods, particularly sheets, blankets, and bed covers, which she says have a very high demand in Ibanda. She has been in this business for 13 years.

Freda first worked at the church as a secretary and this helped her to save some money to start a business.  The  widowed mother of 6  earns 300,000 Uganda shillings from the sale of cloth goods.  She also has additional income from a pension, and from selling bananas.

Freda has a future plan of becoming a distinguished business lady in the Ibanda district. With this Kiva loan, Freda plans to buy more bed covers, blankets and sheets for resale.

loans.use: To buy more bed covers, blankets and sheets for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools for his trade

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Preciosa works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food-vending business in the Philippines.

Preciosa requested a loan of  PHP 19000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. She has been in this business for 4 years. In the future, Preciosa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Sarin (in the photo) has been running a grocery store for three years, while her husband, Marakat is a soldier. They have four children-two sons and two daughters. Two are in school and other two are still young. The family lives in a village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 
Sarin is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy a new motorbike because the old one breaks down very often. She will use another part of the loan to expand her grocery store by buying additional grocery items.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike to replace the old one.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
As a married parent of 9 children, Margarita works hard to support her family.

She has a dried fish (boneless danguit) business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Margarita is borrowing PHP 19000 through NWTF to purchase more stocks of dried fish to sell.

Margarita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business and repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Jabbar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 45 years old, married, and has five children, three of whom work. 

Jabbar has had a grocery store since 2005 which sells soft drinks, juices, cheese, and other dairy products. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His market is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by. 

He is requesting $2100 to renovate his market and to add more foodstuffs. He is optimistic about his business development and hopes that the coming years will continue to bring him positive growth.

loans.use: To renovate his market and to add more foodstuffs.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en:
Marlene is 37 years old and married with five children.

Marlene works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Marlene has borrowed and repaid 19 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the variety store for 8 years.  She also earns income from raising pigs.

Marlene aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
This is Rowena, 36, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Renante, and a mother of two children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rowena operates a barbecue stall near her house. She regularly buys pork, meat and chicken entrails that she prepares to cook and sell in the afternoon at her stall. She also sells dried fish that she orders from her hometown province and mineral water that her husband delivers to nearby apartment units. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 700 in sales every day.

To help continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 16,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more meat, dried fish and mineral water. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rowena dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional meat, dried fish and mineral water for her business

loans.name: Sophuen

texts.en:
Sophuen (pictured) sells boiled eggs and fish, while her husband is a fisherman and drives a motor remoque taxi when he is free from the fishing business.  (A remoque is a motorbike connected to a trailer at the back.)

The couple has been married since 1985.  They have four children -- two sons and two daughters. They live in a village along National Road Number 5, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sophuen is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase a new trailer for her husband because the old one breaks down.

loans.use: To purchase new trailer for her husband.

loans.name: Nimol

texts.en:
Nimol (in the photo) is 48 years old, and her husband, Sothea, is 50 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two sons.  

Nimol runs a grocery store at home, while her husband is a teacher and runs a business of a water utility service. 

Nimol is asking for a loan of $1,000 to fill in the land behind her house. Because the land behind her house floods during the rainy season, she needs to fill it in.

loans.use: To fill in the land behind her house.

loans.name: Marigen

texts.en: Marigen is a hardworking entrepreneur who has had a fishing business in the Philippines for three years and earns additional income selling prawns and crabs. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF, and is now requesting a loan of PHP 10000 to buy additional materials for her fishing business. Marigen dreams of repairing and renovating her family home in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Khem Ma

texts.en:
Khem ma and her husband Hienh live in a village on National Road Number Two, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1992 and have three children - two sons and a daughter.

Khem ma works for a garment factory, while her husband grows small mango trees for sale. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a cow to raise and sell.

loans.use: to purchase a cow to raise.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Virginia works hard to support her family. She has an eatery business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from hog raising, buying and selling of vegetables and root crops, and operating a general store.

Virginia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 14 loans from NWTF and is now requesting a loan of PHP 15000 to buy ingredients for her eatery business. She hopes her hard work will allow her to realize her dream of sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Maysam

texts.en: Maysam and her husband are fishermen. They do fishing from the Mekong River and resell their catch at the market near the village. She is asking for a loan of $500 to repair her fishing gear and boat. The couple lives along National Road Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

loans.use: To repair her fishing gear and boat.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a personal products sales business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock like school supplies, jewelry, and decorations to sell.

Emma has been in this business for 15 years. She earns more income from hog-raising.

Emma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like school supplies, jewelry, and decorations to sell.

loans.name: Jassem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 46 years old, married, and has four children. 

Jassem has owned a flower shop since 2008. He has much experience in making flower arrangements, a good reputation, and is well known in his area. 

He decided to apply for a $3000 loan in order to enlarge his shop and to make a lighted advertising board. He aims to make more money to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop and to make a lighted advertising board.

loans.name: Pho

texts.en:
Pho (pictured with her loom) is a silk weaver, while her husband is a construction worker and farmer. They have been married since 1988 and have seven children--three sons and four daughters. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Pho is asking for another loan of $1,000 to continue her weaving business by purchasing weaving materials. And she will use another part of the loan to assist in her husband’s farming business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and assist in her husband’s farming business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Evelyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fishing nets for her business. She has been in this business for 18 years now.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing nets for her business.

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old, married, and has one child. 

Haydar is a carpenter; in 2010 he opened his own workshop where he makes and repairs furniture. He has more than three years experience, a good reputation, and is well known in his area. 

He decided to apply for $3000 in order to purchase a diesel generator for his workshop. He aims to make more money to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: To purchase a diesel generator for his workshop.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is married with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Evangeline is 33 years old and has two children who are in school.

Evangeline has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Evangeline requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

Evangeline has been in this business for eight years. In the future, Evangeline would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Ra

texts.en:
Ra (pictured here) is 45 years old and her husband, Han is 50 years old. They have been married for almost thirty years and have four children--two sons and two daughters. The family lives in a village about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Ra is a farmer, while her husband is a motor remoque taxi driver. Remoque is a motorbike connected to a trailer at the back. Ra’s husband hopes to drive in Phnom Penh, but driving a remoque is not legal in Phnom Penh.

Therefore, Ra is asking for a loan of $1,000 to assist her husband to buy a "Tuk Tuk". The "Tuk Tuk" is not forbidden.

loans.use: To assist her husband to purchase a "Tuk-Tuk" (motorcycle taxi).

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
Yon is a weaver (pictured here with her loom). She also has a new business, pig-raising, to supplement her income. Her husband is a fisherman and farmer. She is asking for another loan of $200 to help with her husband’s farming business by purchasing a pump. 

The couple lives in a village across the Mekong River, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To help with her husband’s farming business by purchasing a water pump.

loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila is 24 years old and has one child. Nila is married and her child is in school.

Nila is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Nila requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for six years now and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Nila would like to save money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yaeun

texts.en:
Yaeun has full-time employment. Her husband, Hong is a horse cart driver and fisherman and farmer. They have three children--one son and two daughters. All of them attend school. The family is living in a village across Mekong River about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Yaeun is applying for a loan of $200 to help with her husband’s farming business by purchasing fertilizer and paying plowing fees.

Photo: Yaeun and her husband and daughter.

loans.use: To help with her husband’s farming business by purchasing fertilizer and paying plowing fees.

loans.name: Saltanat's Group

texts.en:
Saltanat is the leader of this group. She is 24 and divorced. She takes care of a three-year-old daughter by herself. Saltanat works as an assistant to a judge, and her monthly salary is 7000 soms. She applied for the loan because she needs additional money to start repairing her apartment. In the future she wants to improve their living conditions and give her daughter a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to repair her apartment.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is married and has an abaca (plant fiber) weaving business in the Philippines. She works hard to support her family and has had her business for four years. 

Edna is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy materials for her abaca weaving business. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy weaving materials

loans.name: Chansit Thou

texts.en:
Chansit thou, pictured here, is 30 years old and her husband, Dyna, is 38. The couple lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1998 and have a young daughter.

Chansit thou runs grocery store at home and her husband works for bakery. She is requesting a 1,000 USD loan to buy more grocery items to sell.

loans.use: to buy grocery items to sell

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is 63 years old and is a married woman with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. For the past 20 years, Clarita has operated a food production business in the Philippines.

Clarita is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. In the future, she would like to save money to rent a space at the public market.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Sophat, pictured here, is 51 and works as a tuk-tuk (taxi) driver. In addition, he is also hired by villagers to farm. He uses his income to support his family. Sophat’s wife, Somul, stays at home and does housework. The family lives in the area surrounding Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sophat is requesting a 300 USD loan to repair the house where he lives.

loans.use: to repair his house

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 38 years old and married with three children. For the past 14 years, she has been running a sari-sari (retail) store in the Philippines and she also earns an income from fishing. Mary Jane works hard to provide for her family. She has borrowed and repaid three previous loans from NWTF.

Mary Jane is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell. She aspires to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
This is Imelda, 49, resident of Malibay, Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to George, a driver and mechanic, and mother of five children, two of whom are employed, one in college and the other two are in high school. By the grace of God, Imelda has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college. For most Filipino parents, like Imelda, a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Imelda maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, etc. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Imelda's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 1500 on sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Imelda dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Jaafar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 25 years old, single and lives with seven family members. Two of them work.

Jaafar is an owner of a farm rearing calves and cows since 2006. He has a long experience in this field and has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and he is well known in his area.

He decided to apply for a $2400 loan to make an aluminum ceiling for his farm buildings. He is aiming to earn more profit so as to have the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: To make an aluminum ceiling for his farm buildings.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad is a 51-year-old widow with five children. With two children in school, Trinidad works very hard to provide for them.

Trinidad runs a Sari Sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a 20,000 Philippines pesos loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Trinidad has been in this business for seven years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, beverages, soap, sugar, rice and other groceries. 

In the future, Trinidad would like to save enough money so she could continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Aza's Group

texts.en:
Aza is the leader of this group. She is 39 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she is bringing up two daughters and a son; the daughters study at school and the son is not yet at school, he is preschool age (under seven). 

 Aza works as a teacher of mathematics in the lyceum. Nine years ago she saved 8000 soms and with that money she started to breed cattle. She sells dairy products and resells cattle at a higher price after fattening them. In this way she earns an additional 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Aza wants to purchase more cattle for breeding, fattening and further reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana is 54 years old, married, and has seven children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Ana has a sari-sari store (general store) in the Philippines. Ana requested a 18,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

Ana has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, Ana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo and groceries to sell in her store

loans.name: Amer

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 30 years old, married and has one child.

Amer has been an owner of a food market since 2005 selling soft drinks, juices, and cheese and other dairy products. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His market is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by. 

He decided to apply for a $1500 loan in order to renovate and fix his market’s ceiling, doors, and floor. He is aiming to earn more profit so as to have the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: to renovate and repair his market’s ceiling, doors, and floor.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
This is Emma, 34, a resident of Baseco Port Area, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Alix, who assists her with her business; and mother to their children. Together with her husband and children, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Emma operates a business. What she basically does is buy watches and cell phones at wholesale price and resell them per piece with a little profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices. Aside from this business, she earns through her water refilling station. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 3750 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 26,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Emma dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional products she needs in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her business and build more rental houses.

loans.name: Esau

texts.en:
Esau  is 31 years old and married to Rose. They have two school-going children.

He has a retail shop that he has been running for ten years, and he is applying for his first loan from Kadet Ltd after being introduced by a friend who is a client. The loan will be used to buy flour, sugar, rice and salad.


He hopes to expand his shop to wholesale.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, rice and salad.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, onions, vegetables, and carrots to sell in her store

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 46 years old, married, has two children and lives with five family members. Two of them work.

Aziza has been a tailor since 2000. She makes and repairs women's and kids' clothing. She has a long experience in this field and has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and she is well known in her area.

She decided to apply for $3000 loan in order to buy a tailoring machine, a generator and an air conditioner. She is aiming to gain more profits to offer her the opportunity to provide a better life for her family as a whole.

loans.use: In order to buy a tailoring machine, generator and an air conditioner.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Daisy is married with no children. She is 33 years old and lives in Tangub City. For the past ten years, Daisy has operated a general store to earn a living. Each month, she earns 8,000 PHP from her business. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more inventory for her general store. Daisy has been a member of PMPC since earlier this year. In the future, Daisy hopes that she will be able to expand her little general store.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory for her general store

location.town: Maloro, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Fares

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 37 years old, married and has three children.

Fares has been the owner of a shop for photocopying and mobiles since 2004. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and he has a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He decided to apply for a $3000 loan in order to purchase a tornado phone unlock code. He is aiming to gain more profits to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: to purchase a tornado phone unlock code (unlocks phones remotely).

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en:
Diosdada, a 66-year-old widow of seven grown children living in Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, has been providing for her family's daily needs by selling wood for the past four years, earning PHP 5,148 each month. Because of the high price of petroleum gas and the like, most people in the Philippines use firewood in cooking.

In 2008, Diosdada joined GDMPC and is now requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to acquire more firewood to sell in the local community. With the extra revenue generated, she plans to build an ordinary hut for unsold wood stocks in case of sudden climate change.

loans.use: to acquire firewood to sell in the local community.
